channel.title: Mind blowing and troubling Questions
channel.description:
ok this is what i was asked by my chem teacher:
1.how do you uncook a cooked egg?
2.how do you unburn a burnt table?
he says it is possible, but i just laughed at him. he said if we answer we get extra marks, i do not know if he is trying to make a fool out of us or .....
if any one know please answer.

item.title: Mind blowing and troubling Questions

item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Tree:

ProTip: Explore http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_travel

That, however, is Physics and not Chemics.

Read full topic

item.title: Mind blowing and troubling Questions
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Cooking and uncooking is the same as compiling and decompiling (hell, I can’t think of a good example). You take a file, compile it, and decompile it again. So file A.uncompiled becomes A.compiled, and then turns back into A.uncompiled. Frell said that you have A.uncompiled > A.compiled > B.uncompiled. So you have a different file.

when an egg is cooked, the protein molecules unroll themselves, link up and enclose the water molecules. In order to 'uncook' the egg, you need to detach the protein molecules from each other. By adding a product like sodium borohydride, the egg becomes liquid within three hours. For those who want to try it at home, vitamin C also does the trick.

No idea if it’s true or not. Source: http://observer.guardian.co.uk/foodmonthly/futureoffood/story/0,,1969723,00.html#article_continue and http://j-walkblog.com/index.php?/weblog/posts/uncooking_an_egg/

But unburning a table isn’t possible.

Read full topic

      1.how do you uncook a cooked egg?

      2.how do you unburn a burnt table?

he says it is possible, but i just laughed at him. he said if we answer we get extra marks, i do not know if he is trying to make a fool out of us or …

if any one know please answer.[/quote]

1, feed it to the chicken so it can make another fresh egg

2, recycling.
